element_texts.text: What Is the Midwest?: Family Manuscript Collections

Until recently, the published historical record reflected only the viewpoint of its educated white male authors – making family manuscript collections an important resource for a broader interpretation of history that includes women, children, old people, laborers, farmers, immigrants, and other groups.

Handwritten family letters and diaries, such as the selections featured here, reveal how people did things, and what they believed, valued, and felt. They demonstrate in direct ways how events impact people’s lives, and how personal beliefs and familial relationships influenced public acts and even social change. As such, they enlarge and enrich the study of the American past and provide important background for the concerns of the present.

With your help transcribing handwritten documents, historians and students will be better able to make creative use of the rich resources in the family collections to interpret everyday life and experience from the viewpoint of the participants.

Part of What Is the Midwest, a multidisciplinary project funded by The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation
